content:
# Seraphim (Burning Ones)

## The Throne Vision of Isaiah

'In the year that King Uzziah died I saw the Lord sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up; and the train of his robe filled the temple. Above him stood the seraphim. Each had six wings: with two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew. And one called to another and said: Holy, holy, holy is the LORD of hosts; the whole earth is full of his glory! And the foundations of the thresholds shook at the voice of him who called, and the house was filled with smoke.' (Isaiah 6:1-4)

## The Six Wings Symbolism

**Two covering the face**: Even the highest angels cannot gaze upon the full glory of God; they cover their faces in reverent awe.

**Two covering the feet**: The 'feet' is often a Hebrew euphemism; the covering represents humility and modesty before divine holiness.

**Two for flying**: Ready to execute God's will with speed and obedience.

## The Trisagion (Thrice-Holy)

The seraphim's cry 'Holy, Holy, Holy' (Hebrew: Kadosh, Kadosh, Kadosh) is the source of the Sanctus in Christian liturgy. The threefold repetition emphasizes the superlative holiness of God and, for Christians, prefigures the Trinity.

## Purification Ministry

When Isaiah cries 'Woe is me! For I am lost; for I am a man of unclean lips,' a seraph takes a burning coal from the altar and touches his lips, saying: 'Behold, this has touched your lips; your guilt is taken away, and your sin atoned for' (Isaiah 6:5-7). This demonstrates the seraphim's role as agents of divine purification.

## Theological Significance

Seraphim represent the highest form of created worship. Their burning nature symbolizes divine love that consumes all impurity. They model that even the most exalted beings approach God with reverence and humility.

## The 'Burning Serpents' Connection

The Hebrew 'saraph' also refers to the 'burning serpents' sent among Israel in the wilderness (Numbers 21:6) and the bronze serpent Moses lifted up. Some scholars see a connection to winged serpent imagery in ancient Near Eastern art.
abilities: Divine Glory: Presence fills observers with awe and terror
Six Wings: For rapid divine service and absolute obedience
Holy Fire: Consume sin and impurity
Prophetic Vision: Perceive divine will and future events
Celestial Strength: Immense divine power for executing God's will
description: The Seraphim (Hebrew: seraphim, 'burning ones') are the highest order of angels in Christian angelology, standing closest to God's throne in perpetual adoration. They appear in Isaiah's throne-room vision (Isaiah 6:1-7) as beings of blazing light with six wings: two covering their faces in reverence before God's holiness, two covering their feet in humility, and two for flying in service. Their eternal song 'Holy, Holy, Holy is the LORD of hosts; the whole earth is full of His glory!' (the Trisagion) shakes the foundations and fills the Temple with smoke. One seraph purifies Isaiah's lips with a burning coal from the altar, enabling him to speak God's word. The Seraphim's name suggests beings of consuming divine fire who embody the burning love of God that purifies and transforms.

primarySources.content: In the year that King Uzziah died I saw the Lord sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up; and the train of his robe filled the temple. Above him stood the seraphim. Each had six wings: with two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew. And one called to another and said: 'Holy, holy, holy is the LORD of hosts; the whole earth is full of his glory!' ... Then one of the seraphim flew to me, having in his hand a burning coal that he had taken with tongs from the altar. And he touched my mouth and said: 'Behold, this has touched your lips; your guilt is taken away, and your sin atoned for.'
Then the LORD sent fiery serpents [seraphim] among the people, and they bit the people, so that many people of Israel died... And Moses made a bronze serpent and set it on a pole.
From the serpent's root will come forth an adder, and its fruit will be a flying fiery serpent [saraph].
The name Seraphim clearly indicates their ceaseless and eternal revolution about Divine Principles, their heat and keenness, the exuberance of their intense, perpetual, tireless activity.

oldTestament: Isaiah 6:1-7 - The only explicit appearance of seraphim in the throne vision
Numbers 21:6-8 - Fiery serpents (saraph) in the wilderness
newTestament: Revelation 4:8 - The four living creatures with six wings, saying 'Holy, holy, holy' (often identified with seraphim)
John 3:14-15 - Jesus references the bronze serpent Moses lifted up

worship.liturgicalRole: The Sanctus ('Holy, Holy, Holy, Lord God of Hosts') sung in the Eucharistic liturgy directly derives from the seraphim's eternal praise. In both Eastern and Western rites, this hymn unites earthly worship with the angelic liturgy of heaven.
feastDays: September 29 - Michaelmas, Feast of Saints Michael, Gabriel, and Raphael (celebrates all angelic orders)
November 8 - Synaxis of the Bodiless Powers (Byzantine tradition)
worship.iconography: Seraphim are depicted in red or golden colors symbolizing divine fire. They may appear as six-winged beings with only faces visible, the rest covered by wings. In Orthodox iconography, they often appear in the dome or apse, surrounding Christ in Majesty.
prayers: The Sanctus - 'Holy, Holy, Holy Lord, God of power and might'
Cherubic Hymn - 'We who mystically represent the Cherubim and sing the thrice-holy hymn'

angels.function: Continuous worship and praise of God, purification of sinners, burning with divine love
angels.dwelling: Immediately around the throne of God

patristic: Pseudo-Dionysius - The Celestial Hierarchy (ranks seraphim first)
Thomas Aquinas - Summa Theologiae (seraphim represent love, cherubim knowledge)
Gregory the Great - Homilies on the Gospels
apocryphal: 1 Enoch 20:7 - Gabriel is placed over the serpents, the Garden, and the Cherubim
2 Enoch 19:6 - Six-winged beings in the seventh heaven
jewish: Kedushah prayer - 'Kadosh, Kadosh, Kadosh' from Isaiah 6
Talmud Hullin 91b - Angels sing the Kedushah
Maimonides - Lists seraphim as fifth in his angelology

extendedContent.etymology: From Hebrew 'saraph' (to burn). The seraphim are 'burning ones' - either because they burn with divine love, or because they are agents of purifying fire. The same root appears in the 'fiery serpents' of Numbers 21.
extendedContent.serpentConnection: The Hebrew word 'saraph' is also used for the venomous serpents in Numbers 21 and Isaiah's 'flying serpent.' Some scholars note Ancient Near Eastern winged serpent imagery (Egyptian uraeus, etc.) that may inform the biblical image.
extendedContent.theologicalSignificance: Seraphim embody the highest form of created love for God. Their burning nature represents how divine love consumes all impurity. That even seraphim cover their faces before God teaches the absolute holiness of the Creator.
extendedContent.trinitarian: The threefold 'Holy' (Trisagion) has been interpreted from early Christianity as a veiled reference to the Trinity - Father, Son, and Holy Spirit - each equally holy.
extendedContent.liturgicalImpact: The seraphim's song became the Sanctus of the Eucharistic liturgy, making every Mass/Divine Liturgy a participation in the angelic worship. The Kedushah prayer in Jewish liturgy also derives from Isaiah 6.

weaknesses: Divine Submission: Bound absolutely to God's will
Holiness Paradox: Their nature prevents them from manifesting among the unholy
Singularity: Cannot act independently of divine directive
habitat: Throne of God, highest heavens, divine presence
behavior: Devoted to divine will, burning with holy love, awe-inspiring and terrifying

christian.overview: The Seraphim ("Burning Ones") are the highest angelic order in traditional Christian angelology, appearing in Isaiah 6 as beings of fiery holiness surrounding God's throne. Their perpetual worship establishes the pattern for heavenly liturgy.

biblicalParallels.description: The sole detailed biblical description of Seraphim: six-winged beings covering their faces and feet, flying and calling "Holy, holy, holy is the LORD of hosts."
The Hebrew saraph also designates fiery serpents, suggesting a complex original conception combining serpentine and angelic elements.
The four living creatures's ceaseless "Holy, holy, holy" echoes the Seraphic Trisagion, uniting prophetic and apocalyptic visions of heavenly worship.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers emphasized the Seraphim's burning love for God and their role in purification, as seen in Isaiah's cleansing by the burning coal.

sources.author: Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite
sources.interpretation: The Seraphim are first of the nine orders, characterized by perpetual motion around God, heat, and warmth - symbolizing their ceaseless, burning love and their power to purify others.

sources.author: Thomas Aquinas
sources.interpretation: The name Seraphim signifies "those who are on fire" (incendentes), indicating both the intensity of their love for God and their power to inflame others with divine love.

sources.author: Bernard of Clairvaux
sources.work: Sermons on the Song of Songs
sources.interpretation: The Seraphim represent the highest contemplative union with God, burning with love that is never consumed.

liturgicalSignificance.sanctus: The Seraphic Trisagion ("Holy, holy, holy") is incorporated into both Eastern (Triodion/Oktoechos) and Western (Sanctus of the Mass) Christian liturgy, uniting earthly worship with heavenly.
liturgicalSignificance.theophanyConnection: Isaiah's encounter with the Seraphim establishes the pattern for theophanic experience: overwhelming holiness, human unworthiness, divine purification, and prophetic commission.
liturgicalSignificance.iconography: In Eastern iconography, Seraphim are depicted with six red wings, sometimes with only face and wings visible, emphasizing their fiery nature and proximity to divine light.

medievalSymbolism.hierarchyPosition: The Seraphim occupy the highest position in the Dionysian celestial hierarchy, nearest to God, receiving and transmitting divine light to lower orders.
medievalSymbolism.moralLesson: The covering of face and feet teaches appropriate humility before divine majesty - even the highest angels cannot gaze directly upon God's glory.
medievalSymbolism.artisticRepresentation: Medieval art often depicted Seraphim as red or flame-colored, sometimes with eyes covering their wings (conflated with Cherubim imagery from Ezekiel).

christian.typologicalReading: The burning coal that purified Isaiah's lips prefigures the Eucharist, where believers receive divine fire for purification and empowerment for mission.
christian.etymologicalNote: The Hebrew saraph ("to burn") links to serpent imagery (the "burning" sensation of venom) and to divine fire. This semantic range connects Seraphim to both serpentine guardian beings (like Egyptian uraei) and pure fire as symbol of divine presence.
